dt: {bc}to act as a {d_link|receptacle|receptacle} or container for

dt.t: the cistern {wi}receives{/wi} water from the roof

dt: {bc}to react to in a specified manner
{bc}to accept as authoritative, true, or accurate {bc}{sx|believe||}
{bc}to support the weight or pressure of {bc}{sx|bear||}
{bc}to take (a mark or {d_link|impression|impression}) from the weight of something
{bc}to suffer the hurt or injury of
{bc}to convert incoming radio waves into {d_link|perceptible|perceptible} signals
{bc}to prepare to take possession of the ball from a kick in football

quotes.t: From this time the astronomer was {qword}received{/qword} into familiar friendship, and partook of all their projects and pleasures: his respect kept him attentive, and the activity of Rasselas did not leave much time unengaged.

George, white-gloved, with a gardenia in his buttonhole, stood with his mother and the Major, embowered in the big red and gold drawing room downstairs, to "{qword}receive{/qword}" the guests; and, standing thus together, the trio offered a picturesque example of good looks persistent through three generations.
… his stark and devastating description of Vichy collaborationism (which he based on German and American archives) was rather badly {qword}received{/qword} in France …

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}receivre{/it}, from Latin {it}recipere{/it}, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}capere{/it} to take {ma}{mat|heave:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to come into possession of : acquire
to act as a receptacle or container for
to assimilate through the mind or senses
